ranked_differential_diagnosis.label: Bilateral Asymmetric Noise-Induced Hearing Loss
ranked_differential_diagnosis.rationale_short: History of significant noise exposure (firearms, ATVs). Testing reveals 3000-6000 Hz notched sensorineural hearing loss, with the Right ear approximately 15 dB worse than the left. Asymmetry is likely due to the police radio worn on the right shoulder without ear protection.

ranked_differential_diagnosis.label: Tinnitus
ranked_differential_diagnosis.rationale_short: Patient reports bothersome bilateral ringing, which is a primary symptom of the noise-induced damage.

ranked_differential_diagnosis.label: Normal Hearing Sensitivity (Speech Frequencies)
ranked_differential_diagnosis.rationale_short: Pure Tone Averages (5-7 dB) and Speech Reception Thresholds (5 dB) indicate normal sensitivity in the standard speech range.

ordered_list.rationale_short: To inspect the ear canal and tympanic membrane.
To assess middle ear pressure and compliance.
To evaluate the acoustic reflex arc.
To assess speech reception and recognition.
To characterize the frequency of the patient's tinnitus.
To assess middle ear function and reflectance.

expected_interpretations_by_visit.collective_interpretation: Results indicate normal middle ear function. Audiometry demonstrates a 3000-6000 Hz notched sensorineural hearing loss, with the Right ear approximately 15 dB worse than the left, consistent with noise-induced damage. PTA and SRT are normal, and WRS is excellent. The tinnitus pitch match at 6700 Hz corresponds to the region of worst hearing thresholds.

tests.name: Tympanometry
tests.result_summary: Normal Type A tympanograms bilaterally with peak pressure near 0 daPa.

tests.name: Acoustic Reflexes
tests.result_summary: Present at normal levels (85-90 dB HL) at 1 kHz.

tests.name: Pure Tone Audiometry
tests.result_summary: Normal Pure Tone Averages (Right: 7 dB, Left: 5 dB).

tests.name: Speech Audiometry
tests.result_summary: SRTs align with PTAs (5 dB). Word Recognition Scores are excellent (94% Right, 91% Left) at 85 dB HL.

proposed_items: Hearing conservation education and use of Hearing Protection Devices (HPDs).
counseling_actions: Explain that while hearing in quiet is normal, the tinnitus and difficulty in noise are signs of noise-induced damage.
Emphasize the importance of wearing hearing protection during recreational activities like ATV riding to prevent further deterioration.
Discuss that hearing aids are not currently indicated as speech understanding in quiet is excellent.

escalation.rationale_short: No medical red flags requiring referral; management is audiologic and preventative.

follow_up_plan.objective: Monitor for progression of high-frequency hearing loss.

expected_outcome: Stabilization of hearing thresholds if proper protection is used.
Management of tinnitus annoyance through education and habituation.
